questions.text: Drug of choice for Enterococcus infective endocarditis in a patient allergic to penicillin is?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for treating Enterococcus infections, especially in penicillin-allergic patients. It is effective against most Enterococcus species, including those resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • Choice B. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin, and it is not ideal for a penicillin-allergic patient.
  • Choice C. Aztreonam: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is effective against Gram-negative bacteria but does not cover Enterococcus.
  • Choice D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that is ineffective against Enterococcus

Key Takeaways:

  • Vancomycin is a suitable option for treating Enterococcus infections in penicillin-allergic individuals.
  • Always consider the antibiotic resistance profile of the pathogen.

Reference: Antibiotics for Enterococcal Endocarditis

questions.text: Which one of the following shows drug resistance?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Donovanosis: Donovanosis is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis and is generally not associated with widespread drug resistance.
  • Choice B. Syphilis: Treponema pallidum, the causative organism of syphilis, has no significant resistance to available antibiotics like penicillin.
  • Choice C. Gonorrhea: Neisseria gonorrhoeae has become resistant to multiple antibiotics over time, making it one of the most concerning drug-resistant infections.
  • Choice D. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infections are typically treated with antibiotics, and there is no widespread resistance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gonorrhea is a major public health concern due to increasing antibiotic resistance, especially to cephalosporins and fluoroquinolones.
  • Regular monitoring for drug-resistant strains is important in the management of gonococcal infections.

Reference:

CDC - Gonorrhea Drug Resistance

questions.text: Which of the following does not have a polysaccharide capsule?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Haemophilus influenzae type B: This bacterium has a polysaccharide capsule that is an important virulence factor.
  • Choice B. Pneumococcus: Streptococcus pneumoniae also has a polysaccharide capsule that helps in evading the immune system.
  • Choice C. Neisseria meningitidis: Neisseria meningitidis possesses a polysaccharide capsule that aids in its virulence.
  • Choice D. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B is a virus, and viruses do not have a polysaccharide capsule. Instead, they have a protein-based envelope or capsid.

Key Takeaways:

  • Polysaccharide capsules are important virulence factors for many bacteria, helping them evade the immune response.
  • Hepatitis B is a virus and does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

Reference:

Polysaccharide Capsules and Infection

questions.text: Among the following, which needs only female pathogens and undergoes self-fertilization (parthenogenesis)?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Trichuris: Trichuris trichiura requires both male and female worms for reproduction.
  • Choice B. Strongyloides: Strongyloides stercoralis can undergo parthenogenesis, where only female worms are needed for reproduction, and they can produce offspring without males.
  • Choice C. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma species, like hookworms, require both male and female worms for reproduction.
  • Choice D. Enterobius: Enterobius vermicularis, the pinworm, requires both male and female worms for reproduction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Strongyloides is unique in its ability to reproduce via parthenogenesis, where only females are required for reproduction.
  • Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction that allows for the continuation of the species without males.

Reference:

Strongyloides Stercoralis Overview

• Choice A. Infective endocarditis: Streptococcus agalactiae is not a common cause of infective endocarditis.
  • Choice B. Dental caries: Dental caries are commonly caused by Streptococcus mutans, not agalactiae.
  • Choice C. Tonsillitis and pharyngitis: Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A) is typically responsible for tonsillitis and pharyngitis, not agalactiae.
  • Choice D. Neonatal sepsis: Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is a leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is a major cause of neonatal infections, including sepsis and meningitis.
  • Pregnant women are often screened for Group B Streptococcus to prevent neonatal infections.

Reference:

Group B Streptococcus in Pregnancy

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. ss RNA
2. ds RNA
3. ss DNA
4. ds DNA
A) HPV
B) Rota
C) Parvo
D) Covid-19
questions.solution:
• Choice A. HPV: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a double-stranded DNA virus (ds DNA).
  • Choice B. Rota: Rotavirus is a double-stranded RNA virus (ds RNA).
  • Choice C. Parvo: Parvovirus is a single-stranded DNA virus (ss DNA).
  • Choice D. Covid-19: SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, is a single-stranded RNA virus (ss RNA).

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding the structure of viral genomes helps in classifying viruses and choosing appropriate diagnostic methods.
  • Rotavirus and SARS-CoV-2 are important pathogens in their respective fields.

Reference:

CDC - Virus Types

questions.text: Swollen Bartholin opening, vaginal discharge, clinical picture of PID, gram-negative intracellular diplococci.
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the causative agent of gonorrhea, which can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and presents with gram-negative intracellular diplococci on Gram stain.
  • Choice B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis can also cause PID but does not typically show intracellular diplococci on Gram stain.
  • Choice C. Chancroid: Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, and presents as painful ulcers, not intracellular diplococci.
  • Choice D. E. Coli: coli is a common pathogen in urinary tract infections but is not a common cause of PID or associated with intracellular diplococci.

Key Takeaways:

  • PID caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae can present with specific Gram stain findings, including intracellular diplococci.
  • Gonorrhea remains a major public health concern and requires appropriate antimicrobial treatment.

Reference:

CDC - Gonorrhea

questions.text: Patient suffering from diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows an oocyst measuring 15 to 20 microns. Identify the structure.
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Cystoisospora belli: This protozoan causes diarrhea and is typically characterized by oocysts measuring around 15-20 microns.
  • Choice B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cayetanensis also causes diarrhea but is typically characterized by oocysts that measure slightly larger than Cystoisospora.
  • Choice C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are smaller (approximately 4-6 microns), not in the 15-20 micron range.
  • Choice D. Candida albicans: Candida is a fungus and does not produce oocysts.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cystoisospora belli is a protozoan that can cause prolonged diarrhea, often seen in immunocompromised patients.
  • Accurate stool microscopy is crucial for identifying the causative agent of parasitic diarrhea.

Reference:

Cystoisospora belli

questions.text: Best diagnostic test for malaria speciation.
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Giemsa stained thick smear: Thick smears are useful for detecting malaria parasites but not for speciation.
  • Choice B. Giemsa stained thin smear: Thin smears allow for better identification and speciation of Plasmodium species, including falciparum and P. vivax.
  • Choice C. Acridine orange stained thin slide: Acridine orange is useful for detecting nucleic acids but is not specific for malaria speciation.
  • Choice D. Calcofluor white: This is used to stain fungi, not for malaria parasites.

Key Takeaways:

  • A Giemsa-stained thin smear is the gold standard for diagnosing and speciation of malaria.
  • Thick smears are used for detecting parasitemia, while thin smears help in species identification.

Reference:

Malaria Diagnosis

questions.text: Extensive history of dengue hemorrhagic fever, retro-orbital pain, and fever for more than 5 days. The best test for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. NS1 antigen: NS1 is helpful in the early stages of infection, but RT-PCR provides more specific and reliable results for diagnosis.
  • Choice B. IgM capture ELISA: IgM ELISA can help in diagnosing recent infection but is not ideal in the acute phase.
  • Choice C. RT PCR: RT-PCR is the most reliable method for diagnosing acute dengue infection, especially in the first few days of illness.
  • Choice D. Viral culture: Viral culture is rarely used in clinical settings due to its long turnaround time.

Key Takeaways:

  • RT-PCR is the gold standard for diagnosing dengue in the early phase of infection.
  • NS1 antigen testing and IgM detection are complementary, but PCR remains the most definitive.

Reference:

Dengue Diagnosis

• Choice A) Transient aplastic anemia - Parvovirus B19 is known to cause transient aplastic anemia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemoglobinopathies.
  • Choice B) Aplastic anemia in immunocompromised person - Parvovirus B19 can cause persistent aplastic anemia in immunocompromised individuals, but not in the general sense as a common complication.
  • Choice C) Nonimmune hydrops fetalis - This condition is a known complication of parvovirus B19 infection, especially in pregnant women.
  • Choice D) Fever with petechial rash - While not the most common presentation, parvovirus B19 may also present with fever and a rash, such as in erythema infectiosum.

Key Takeaway:

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause transient aplastic anemia and hydrops fetalis, especially in pregnant women. It can also be responsible for certain rash presentations. Immunocompromised individuals may experience persistent aplastic anemia.

questions.text: Which organism is transmitted through all blood components?
questions.solution:
• Choice A) Malaria - Malaria is transmitted through all blood components, including red blood cells, plasma, and platelets.
  • Choice B) Filaria - Filariasis is transmitted through mosquito bites and does not generally transmit through blood transfusion.
  • Choice C) Toxoplasma - Toxoplasmosis is typically transmitted through contaminated food, water, or congenital transmission but not via all blood components.
  • Choice D) Syphilis - Syphilis can be transmitted through blood, but it is less common to transmit through all components compared to malaria.

Key Takeaway:

Malaria can be transmitted through all blood components, emphasizing the importance of screening blood products for malaria in transfusion practices.

choices.text: Assertion and reason both are correct
Assertion and reason both are wrong
Assertion is correct but reason is wrong
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: Myocarditis is a commonly known complication of facial diphtheria.
Reason: Diphtheria causes bacteremia.
questions.solution:
• Choice A) Assertion and reason both are correct - The assertion about myocarditis is true, but the reason is incorrect. Diphtheria is usually localized and does not cause bacteremia directly.
  • Choice B) Assertion and reason both are wrong - The assertion about myocarditis is true, but the reason is wrong.
  • Choice C) Assertion is correct but reason is wrong - Myocarditis can occur as a complication of diphtheria, but it is not due to bacteremia; it is related to toxin production.
  • Choice D) Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct - Myocarditis is indeed a complication, but it is due to the diphtheria toxin, not bacteremia.

Key Takeaway:

Myocarditis is a recognized complication of diphtheria, but the pathophysiology is related to the diphtheria toxin rather than bacteremia.

choices.text: Assertion and reason both are correct
Assertion and reason both are wrong
Assertion is correct but reason is wrong
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: Processing sputum by adding N-acetylcysteine and NaOH for mycobacterial culture.
Reason: N-acetylcysteine kills bacteria, NaOH liquefies sputum.
questions.solution:
• Choice A) Assertion and reason both are correct - N-acetylcysteine does not kill bacteria; it helps in breaking down mucus, while NaOH is used to decontaminate the sample.
  • Choice B) Assertion and reason both are wrong - The reasoning and assertion are partially correct but need clarification.
  • Choice C) Assertion is correct but reason is wrong - The assertion is correct as N-acetylcysteine helps break down mucus, but it does not kill bacteria. NaOH is used for decontamination, not liquefaction.
  • Choice D) Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct - The assertion is correct about the use of N-acetylcysteine, but the reason provided is wrong.

Key Takeaway:

N-acetylcysteine is used to break down mucus in sputum processing, while NaOH is used for decontaminating the sample, particularly for mycobacterial cultures.

choices.text: Inhibits the release of GABA and glycine

questions.text: The patient was injured with rusted metal. Mechanism of action of tetanus?
questions.solution:
• Choice A) Inhibits the release of GABA and glycine - Tetanus toxin inhibits neurotransmitter release (GABA and glycine), leading to muscle spasms and rigidity.
  • Choice B) Inhibits ACE - This option is not related to the mechanism of tetanus.
  • Choice C) Inhibits metal ion transporter - This is not the mechanism of action for tetanus.
  • Choice D) None of the above - This is incorrect as the mechanism of tetanus is inhibition of GABA and glycine release.

Key Takeaway:

Tetanus toxin prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine, causing the characteristic muscle rigidity and spasms.

questions.text: How to disinfect the tip of a pipette?
questions.solution:
• Choice A) Autoclave - The most reliable method for sterilizing laboratory equipment, including pipettes.
  • Choice B) Hot air oven - Can sterilize but is less common for pipettes compared to autoclaving.
  • Choice C) Ethanol 70% - While ethanol can disinfect, it does not sterilize to the extent an autoclave would.
  • Choice D) Microwave - Microwaving is not a recommended method for sterilizing pipettes.

Key Takeaway:

Autoclaving is the preferred and most reliable method to sterilize laboratory equipment such as pipettes.

questions.text: Mother with a history of painful genital lesions one year ago. Her few days old child has CNS symptoms and multinucleated giant cells. Cause is?
questions.solution:
• Choice A) VZV - Varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, not typically associated with CNS symptoms in neonates.
  • Choice B) HSV2 - Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) can cause neonatal herpes, especially when transmitted during delivery, leading to CNS involvement.
  • Choice C) HIV - While HIV can lead to CNS complications in neonates, it typically presents differently than HSV-2.
  • Choice D) Hep-B - Hepatitis B can cause chronic liver disease, not typically CNS involvement in neonates.

Key Takeaway:

Neonatal herpes (HSV-2) is a severe infection that can result from vertical transmission during birth, often leading to CNS involvement, as seen in this case.
